content:
If I understand your question, it sounds to me like you have accidentally enabled Threaded View, which groups conversations into a tree-like formation. There's a small icon that toggles this on and off. See the attached images.

There's also a setting to control the default view for newly-created folders. See (in Windows <Tools | Settings | Appearance | Sorting and Threading | Default Threading>).
creator: rednoise

content: yes it works thanks a lot!
creator: yura_svcom

content:
A low-tech approach would be each time after using to do this: - exit thunderbird - copy the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder to a USB stick - then DELETE the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder

When reusing, - first, copy the thunerbird folder back to appdata\roaming and restart thunderbird

The only other solution I'm aware of would be to create a separate user account on the PC in Windows and set up your thunderbird in the private Windows account. Otherwise, there is no guarantee. And anyone sneaky or wanting to peek at your local mail could always just copy the message folders from within the proflle. the message files are not encrypted and easily viewed with several free online tools.
creator: davidsk

content:
Hi David,

Thank you for the quick reply. The idea of copying the appdata\roaming\thunderbird folder might be a good idea. Maybe I could simply move that to a network folder where only I have access and use the login to the network folder instead of the password. If that does not work out the USB drive is also a good idea.

Creating different user accounts would certainly be the easiest way. Unfortunately, that does not work out with our network structure where we have split right to particular network folders based on the user and sharing those with the private accounts is not possible while using the private accounts would prevent the people from their actual work...

Thank you again! Juergen
creator: juergen

content:
I think that Thunderbird installed on the hard disk can use a profile directly off a USB drive, so there may be no need to be copying things off and on it.

Also, I've read that Thunderbird Portable can run directly off a USB drive.

I don't have personal experience with either of these, but they're worth considering.
creator: rednoise

content:
What Lin says is true. That's a super idea. Then you could access your account from any PC anywhere. You can get the portable version at https://portableapps.com/apps/internet/thunderbird_portable and it is a legal and supported product. You would then have thunderbird and your profile on the USB. A big thanks to Lin for the suggestion. (I shudda' thought of it too, since I'm running a portable version myself.)

On your network observation, if thunderbird would 'see' the profile as a local drive, you could put the profile on the network, with some steps not explained unless you ask. But Lin's approach is slicker and quicker and fool-proof. :)
creator: davidsk

content:

content: I guess I've found the problem just now: In disk space the setting delete messages over 30 days old was selected. And actually thew oldest message i can find is from the 17th of January. What I don't understand though is, how this could have become selected. I would have never set an option like that, not willingly. Thank you anyway. Kind regards Frank
creator: Frank207

content:
Maybe you will be lucky despite your bad luck! first of all: actually please do not compact folders if Thunderbird prompts you since if you do (or already did that) your old messages are definitively LOST.


I just tested the Disk space setting with over 10 days old in the POP account in one of my test profiles. As I suspected the older messages were deleted on restart and didn't appear in the Trash folder. But when I opened the Inbox file in the profile folder I saw that the deleted messages were still present in the Inbox file, but marked as déleted by X-Mozilla-Status: 0009 So I installed the extension "Undelete" from here https://www.ggbs.de/extensions/Undelete.html and successfully recovered the deleted messages in a folder Inbox_undeleted in Local folders (see images)
creator: Mapenzi

content: Thank you for you help. I didn't know of "undelete" so thank you for that hint. I tried it on every sub-folder and on every sub-sub-folder but it only recovered 5 files from inbox which I had neither deleted nor moved to the trash. What's more is that not only I don't know how this "Delete Files which are older than 30 days" setting was changed but neither when, which means that some messages may have been deleted quite a while ago which in turn means that they probably have been written over a number of times:-( I will try to recover something from the file system which unfortunately is XFS but I guess that there won't be a lot to recover neither. Thank you for your help Kind Regards Frank from rainy Italy
creator: Frank207

content:
Don't lament about why, how and by whom the setting of "older than 30 days" has been fixed since you'll never know. It's certainly no bug and any of us will commit an error one day or the other, it's human. The best precaution against such "unwanted errors" is to create regularly backup copies of the Thunderbird profile folder, in particular if you are working with POP accounts.

The result that you couldn't restore the deleted messages with the "Undelete" add-on can easily be explained by the fact that in my test after automatic deletion of a big number of messages older than 10 days Thunderbird prompted me to compact folders which I denied since a knew that thereafter the deleted messages could no longer de recovered. Maybe in your case Thunderbird, depending on your settings for compacting folders, has done the compacting silently without asking you to confirm. Which for me is a reason to never allow compacting silently and without warning me before.
creator: Mapenzi

content: It appears you are belng blocked, possibly due to an error in the SMTP configuration. Posting a screenshot of the SMTP server settings pane may generate some suggestions. re you able to send email to anyone, or no one?
creator: davidsk

content:
Good evening David, I had another problem today because my Free email account was inactive and forced me to change my password. So, I deleted all the data from my Free email account, and once my email was restored, I re-entered my login details on Thunderbird. The same scenario as before occurred: my outgoing emails worked directly on Zimbra but wouldn't send via Thunderbird. Receiving emails through Thunderbird worked fine. However, the error message was simpler: "The message could not be sent because the connection to the outgoing server (SMTP) 'smtp.free.fr' has timed out. Please try again."

Finally, after searching for a solution, I managed to resolve the problem by modifying the outgoing server settings and changing the port to 465. Thank you, David, for your advice.
creator: christianroche12

content: Thanks for the feedback. I'm glad all is well.

content: Theoretically you can navigate in the Calendar tab using the tabulator key. But it will take you an eternity to go there where to want to be. Maybe an add-on but I don't know any which would do what you like. I'm on Mac and I have always used the macOS Calendar app to create, edit and/or modify my events. It is only since Thunderbird supports CalDav that I created my iCloud calendar in Thunderbird in order to synchronise between Mac, Thunderbird an iPhone. The Calendar app also allows a higher number of reminders.

content:

It just seems like using arrow keys would go to the next day or the previous day is intuitively obvious. I think this has worked with every calendar tool I've used since the Mac or Windows were invented (yes, I'm that old). It's surprising to me that this doesn't work with Thunderbird.

Cheers, Tim

content:
A couple of things you can do to mitigate that:

- Stick to the Extended Support Release (ESR) versions. There will be no significant UI changes for at least a year.

- Make sure that Auto-Update is turned off (in Windows <Tools | Settings | General | Updates | Check for updates, but let me choose whether to install them>.
creator: rednoise

content:
First of all thank you! I will do that. Unfortunately this doesn't solve a very important problem i addressed. I would call myself a Poweruser an even I think that this search bar that replaced the whole toolbar is absolutely inconvenient. And now imagine a 60+ person like mi mom or perhaps your Nana that's sitting on her computer and now she can't use her Emailprogramm any more. Thas a punch in the face for them how can your developers assume that they could handle that alone?! You should definitely consider a rollback and adding different presets in the toolbar settings. Also you definitely give your users the option to update and keep their familiar UI and the option to "try" the new UI and I insist on the word "try" because they should be able to go back to their known UI. I really hope this will find its way into the developer meetings because or parents grandparents aunts and uncles deserve more peace when dealing with computers and I hope that especially you folks at Mozilla understand this.

Best regards, Dilan Adler
creator: dilan.adler

content:
> Every time a rollout breaks the visual layout or hides basic functions, she is unable to use her email until I step in to fix what the update messed up.

Sorry you are having trouble. You are referring to the Unified Toolbar, which is the area topmost in the UI?

We are not aware of any current bugs in this area, on updates or under any conditions - https://mzl.la/4rYtgYp lists unified toolbar bug reports created in the past 6 months and none are notable - this includes both ESR and release channels.

But perhaps you noticed a couple bugs fixed several months ago that accidentally hid the menu bar

  • Bug 1979002 - Menu bar is turned off on update from 128.12.0esr to 140.0.1esr because of migration error. A result of a code cleanup.
  • Bug 1989026 - Upgrading from 142.x to 143 will hide the Menu bar if it was previously set to be visible

Also, there have been no changes in the UI (message list and toolbars) in the past several months - again, both ESR and release channels. I double checked the release notes to make sure.

But it is possible I have missed something. Therefore, we would need to know more about your situation. Some questions about the system(s) that are having trouble:

  • What OS(s)?
  • What is the last version(s) that had trouble?
  • If running Windows, are you using any cleanup tools like CCleaner?

I well understand the issue of supporting older users, so please help us help you.
creator: wsmwk

content: I did remember, if you are using release channel versions 145.0, 146.0, etc, that there have been some naming issues that you would see in the UI.

content:
It sounds like you're creating an HTML-format message and you're using Paragraph Style, rather than Body Style. That can be changed while composing the message by selecting the different style from the drop-down list at the left of the composing window toolbar.

The default style can be changed in ([in Windows] - <Tools | Options | Settings | Composition | HTML Style | Use Paragraph format instead of Body Text by default>.)
creator: rednoise

content: You can move most icons from any of the categories to the Mail toolbar, but you can only move categorize icons to the function's toolbar. e.g., for Calendar, you can move Print, Go to Today, and Find Events to the Calendar toolbar, but not to the Mail toolbar.

content: Yes, 995 would be the norm, and I think you're right on that. Changing the DNS is a delicate task, one I avoid. If your domain registrar is different from the web host, I suggest contacting them. I presume you can send, but not receive? And you never shared any error messages. Why did you change DNS settings? I have no answer, but you have shared no details here. This seems to not be an email issue from your description, but a domain issue. Possibly a different forum where you could share explicitly what you changed in DNS and why, you might get better assistance.

content: Assuming this is an IMAP account, it is possible that the folders became unsubscribed. Thunderbird has no size limitations. If you are able to see the missing folders from another client, then resetting with Thunderbird should simply be to resubscribe. That global database just contains an index, but not the messages themselves. My suggestion: log onto your online account and verify that the folders are there. then, highlight account in folder pane, right-click and then select 'subscribe' and look for the folders.
creator: davidsk

content: error 550 5.7.1 is not specific, but usually means a policy violation. that is, the receiving provider may suspect spam. Your posted message states that the email provider is blocked, so that seems the appropriate direction to resolve this. contact your email provider. What you can do is to check your SMTP settings to ensure that you are using the appropriate authentication for the account.
